panels.description: - The number of threads that are not sleeping
panels.title: ★ Threads running

panels.description: - The number of row locks currently waited for by operations on InnoDB tables
panels.title: ★ Row lock current waits

panels.description: - The number of times waited for free buffer. innodb_buffer_pool_wait_free
panels.title: ★ Buffer pool wait free

panels.description:
- The total wait time of the summarized events that are timed.
- = Active session
panels.title: ★ SQL Time (per sec.)

panels.description: The time spent waiting for locks.
panels.title: Lock Time (per sec.)

panels.description: The Number of executions per second of statements.
panels.title: Executions

panels.description: - The number of currently open connections
panels.title: Current Connections

panels.description: - The number of statements executed by server
panels.title: ★ Questions

panels.description:
- read rows = read_rnd_next + read_next + read_prev
- read_rnd_next: The number of requests to read the next row in the data file. This value is high if you are doing a lot of table scans.
- read_next : The number of requests to read the next row in key order. This value is incremented if you are querying an index column with a range constraint or if you are doing an index scan.
- read_prev: The number of requests to read the previous row in key order. This read method is mainly used to optimize ORDER BY ... DESC.
panels.title: Handler - read rows

panels.description: - The number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time.
panels.title: ★ Slow queries

panels.description: - The number of logical read requests
panels.title: Logical reads

panels.description: - The number of requests to read directly from disk. innodb_buffer_pool_reads
panels.title: Disk reads

panels.description: - The number of bytes received from all clients.
panels.title: N/W - In

panels.description: - The number of bytes sent from all clients.
panels.title: N/W - Out

panels.description: The number of joins performed by the statement which did not use an index.
panels.title: ★ select_full_join

panels.description: The number of joins performed by statements which used a full scan of the first table.
panels.title: ★ select_scan

panels.description: Top SQL ordered by Elapsed Time

targets.expr:
topk(200, 
     sum ((mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_seconds_total{alias=~"$alias"} -
           mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_seconds_total{alias=~"$alias"} offset $__range)
          or mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_seconds_total{alias=~"$alias"})
     by (job, alias, instance, digest, digest_text, schema)
    )

topk(200, 
     sum ((mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_total{alias=~"$alias"} -
           mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_total{alias=~"$alias"} offset $__range)
          or mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_total{alias=~"$alias"})
     by (job, alias, instance, digest, digest_text, schema)
    )

topk(200, 
     sum ((mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_rows_examined_total{alias=~"$alias"} -
           mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_rows_examined_total{alias=~"$alias"} offset $__range)
          or mysql_perf_schema_events_statements_rows_examined_total{alias=~"$alias"})
     by (job, alias, instance, digest, digest_text, schema)
    )

panels.description:
- The total wait time of the summarized events that are timed.
- = Active session
panels.title: ★ SQL Time (/s)

panels.description: The time spent waiting for locks.
panels.title: Lock Time (/s)

panels.description: The number of executions per second of statements.
panels.title: Executions

panels.description: The number of rows read during statements' execution.
panels.title: rows_examined

panels.description: The number of rows affected by statements.
panels.title: rows_affected

panels.description: The number of rows returned.
panels.title: rows_sent

panels.description: The number of on-disk temporary tables created.
panels.title: created_tmp_disk_tables

panels.description: The number of temporary tables created.
panels.title: created_tmp_tables

panels.description: The number of merge passes by the sort algorithm performed by statements.
panels.title: sort_merge_passes

panels.description: The number of sorts performed by statements which used a full table scan.
panels.title: sort_scan

panels.description: The number of sorts performed by statements which used a range.
panels.title: sort_range

panels.description: The number of rows sorted.
panels.title: sort_rows

panels.description: The number of joins performed by the statement which did not use an index.
panels.title: ★ select_full_join

panels.description: The number of joins performed by statements which used a full scan of the first table.
panels.title: ★ select_scan

panels.description: The number of joins performed by the statement which used a range search of the first table.
panels.title: full_range_join

panels.description: The number of joins performed by the statement which used a range of the first table.
panels.title: select_range

panels.description: The number of joins without keys performed by statements that check for key usage after each row.
panels.title: select_range_check

panels.description: The number of times no index was found.
panels.title: no_index_used

panels.description: The number of times no good index was found.
panels.title: no_good_index_used

panels.description: The number of errors. 0 if SQLSTATE signifies completion (starting with 00) or warning (01), otherwise 1.
panels.title: errors

panels.description: The number of warnings from the diagnostics area.
panels.title: warnings

panels.description: Connection Usages(%) = threads_connected / max_connections
panels.title: Connection Usages

panels.description: - The number of currently open connections
panels.title: Current Connections

panels.description: The number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server.
panels.title: Connection attempts

panels.description: The number of threads created to handle connections. If Threads_created is big, you may want to increase the thread_cache_size value. The cache miss rate can be calculated as Threads_created/Connections.
panels.title: Thraeds created

panels.description:
- The number of connections that were aborted because the client died without closing the connection properly.
- https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/communication-errors.html
panels.title: Aborted clients

panels.description:
The number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server. 
- A client attempts to access a database but has no privileges for it.
- A client uses an incorrect password.
- A connection packet does not contain the right information.
- It takes more than connect_timeout seconds to obtain a connect packet
- https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/server-system-variables.html
panels.title: Aborted connects

panels.description: - The number of statements executed by server
panels.title: Questions

panels.description: - The number of times each "select" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - select

panels.description: - The number of times each "insert" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - insert

panels.description: - The number of times each "update" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - update

panels.description: - The number of times each "delete" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - delete

panels.description: - The number of times each "commit" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - commit

panels.description: - The number of times each "rollback" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - rollback

panels.description: - The number of times each "insert_select" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - insert_select

panels.description: - The number of times each "update_multi" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - update_multi

panels.description: - The number of times each "insert_select" statements has been executed.
panels.title: Com - delete_multi

panels.description: - read_rnd_next: The number of requests to read the next row in the data file. This value is high if you are doing a lot of table scans.
panels.title: Handler - read rows by table scan

panels.description:
- read rows by index = read_next + read_prev
- read_next : The number of requests to read the next row in key order. This value is incremented if you are querying an index column with a range constraint or if you are doing an index scan.
- read_prev: The number of requests to read the previous row in key order. This read method is mainly used to optimize ORDER BY ... DESC.
panels.title: Handler - read rows by index

panels.description: - The number of requests to insert a row in a table.
panels.title: Handler - insert

panels.description: - The number of requests to update a row in a table.
panels.title: Handler - update

panels.description: - The number of requests to deletea row in a table.
panels.title: Handler - delete

panels.description: - The number of internal COMMIT statements.
panels.title: Handler - commit

panels.description: - The number of requests for a storage engine to perform a rollback operation.
panels.title: Handler - rollback

panels.description: - The number of requests to insert a row in a table.
panels.title: Handler - insert

panels.description:
- read rows by index = read_first + read_last
- read_first : The number of times the first entry in an index was read. If this value is high, it suggests that the server is doing a lot of full index scans (for example, SELECT col1 FROM foo, assuming that col1 is indexed).
- read_last: The number of requests to read the last key in an index. With ORDER BY, the server issues a first-key request followed by several next-key requests, whereas with ORDER BY DESC, the server issues a last-key request followed by several previous-key requests.
panels.title: Handler - Index full scan

panels.description: The number of requests to read a row based on a key. If this value is high, it is a good indication that your tables are properly indexed for your queries.
panels.title: Handler - read_key

panels.description: - The number of logical read requests
panels.title: Logical reads

panels.description:
- The total number of data reads (OS file reads).
- innodb_data_reads = innodb_buffer_pool_reads
panels.title: Innodb_data_reads (Disk reads)

panels.description: The total number of data reads (OS file reads).
panels.title: Innodb_data_writes

panels.description:
The number of fsync() operations so far. The frequency of fsync() calls is influenced by the setting of the innodb_flush_method configuration option.

Counts the number of fdatasync() operations if innodb_use_fdatasync is enabled.
panels.title: Innodb_data_fsyncs

panels.description: The number of doublewrite operations that have been performed.
panels.title: Innodb_dblwr_writes

panels.description: The amount of data that have been written to the doublewrite buffer. so far, in bytes.
panels.title: Innodb_dblwr_written (bytes)

panels.description: The number of rows read from InnoDB tables.
panels.title: Innodb_rows_read

panels.description: The amount of data read since the server was started (in bytes).
panels.title: Innodb_data_read (bytes)

panels.description: The amount of data written so far, in bytes.
panels.title: Innodb_data_written (bytes)

panels.description: The current number of pending reads.
panels.title: Innodb_data_pending - reads

panels.description: The current number of pending writes.
panels.title: Innodb_data_pending - writes

panels.description: The current number of pending fsync() operations. The frequency of fsync() calls is influenced by the setting of the innodb_flush_method configuration option.
panels.title: Innodb_data_pending - fsyncs

panels.description: The amount of pages created by operations on InnoDB tables, in bytes.
panels.title: Innodb_pages_created (bytes)

panels.description: The amount of pages read by operations on InnoDB tables, in bytes.
panels.title: Innodb_pages_read (bytes)

panels.description: The amount of pages written by operations on InnoDB tables, in bytes.
panels.title: Innodb_pages_written (bytes)

panels.description: The number of joins that perform table scans because they do not use indexes. If this value is not 0, you should carefully check the indexes
panels.title: Join - Select_full_join

panels.description: The number of joins that did a full scan of the first table.
panels.title: Join - Select_scan

panels.description: The number of joins that used a range search on a reference table.
panels.title: Join - Select_full_range_join

panels.description: The number of joins that used ranges on the first table. This is normally not a critical issue even if the value is quite large.
panels.title: Join - Select_range

panels.description: The number of joins without keys that check for key usage after each row. If this is not 0, you should carefully check the indexes of your tables.
panels.title: Join - Select_range_check

panels.description: The number of merge passes that the sort algorithm has had to do. If this value is large, you should consider increasing the value of the sort_buffer_size system variable.
panels.title: ★ Sort_merge_passes

panels.description: The number of sorted rows.
panels.title: Sort_rows

panels.description: The number of sorts that were done using ranges.
panels.title: Sort_range

panels.description: The number of sorts that were done by scanning the table.
panels.title: Sort_scan

panels.description:
The number of internal on-disk temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

You can compare the number of internal on-disk temporary tables created to the total number of internal temporary tables created by comparing Created_tmp_disk_tables and Created_tmp_tables values.
panels.title: ★ Created_tmp_disk_tables

panels.description: The number of internal temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.
panels.title: Created_tmp_tables

panels.description: How many temporary files mysqld has created.
panels.title: Created_tmp_files

panels.description: How many temporary files mysqld has created.
panels.title: XXX

panels.description: The number of tables that have been opened. If Opened_tables is big, your table_open_cache value is probably too small.
panels.title: ★ Opened_tables

panels.description: The number of tables that are open.
panels.title: Open_tables

panels.description: The number of files that have been opened with my_open() (a mysys library function). Parts of the server that open files without using this function do not increment the count.
panels.title: Opened_files

panels.description: The number of files that are open. This count includes regular files opened by the server. It does not include other types of files such as sockets or pipes. Also, the count does not include files that storage engines open using their own internal functions rather than asking the server level to do so.
panels.title: Open_files

panels.description: - The number of times waited for free buffer. innodb_buffer_pool_wait_free
panels.title: ★ buffer_pool_wait_free

panels.description: = 1 - (innodb_buffer_pool_reads/innodb_buffer_pool_read_requests)
panels.title: ★ Innodb Buffer Hit %

panels.description: The size in bytes of the buffer pool, the memory area where InnoDB caches table and index data.
panels.title: Innodb BP Size

panels.description: The total bytes of free apges in the InnoDB buffer pool.
panels.title: Innodb BP - free

panels.description: The total bytes of data pages in the InnoDB buffer pool. It includes both dirty and clean pages.
panels.title: Innodb BP - data

panels.description: The total bytes of dirty pages in the InnoDB buffer pool.
panels.title: Innodb BP - dirty

panels.description: The number of times that the log buffer was too small and a wait was required for it to be flushed before continuing.
panels.title: ★ innodb_log_waits

panels.description: The number of write requests for the InnoDB redo log.
panels.title: log_write_requests

panels.description: The number of physical writes to the InnoDB redo log file.
panels.title: innodb_log_writes

panels.description:
- The amount of data written to the InnoDB redo log since the last checkpoint.
- innodb_checkpoint_age = Log sequence number - Last checkpoint at
panels.title: Innodb Checkpoint Age

panels.description:
- The redo log occupancy is the percentage of the InnoDB redo log capacity that is taken up by dirty pages that have not yet been flushed to the physical InnoDB tablespace files in a checkpoint.
- innodb_log_occupancy = innodb_checkpoint_age / innodb_log_group_capacity
panels.title: Redo Log Occupancy %

panels.description: The number of transactions that used the binary log cache.
panels.title: Binlog_cache_use

panels.description: The number of nontransactional statements that used the binary log statement cache.
panels.title: Binlog_stmt_cache_use

panels.description:
- The number of transactions that used the temporary binary log cache but that exceeded the value of binlog_cache_size and used a temporary file to store statements from the transaction.
- The number of nontransactional statements that caused the binary log transaction cache to be written to disk is tracked separately in the Binlog_stmt_cache_disk_use status variable.
panels.title: Binlog_cache_disk_use

panels.description: The number of nontransaction statements that used the binary log statement cache but that exceeded the value of binlog_stmt_cache_size and used a temporary file to store those statements.
panels.title: Binlog_stmt_cache_disk_use

panels.description: Total number of transactions committed to the binary log.
panels.title: Binlog_commits

panels.description:
- Total number of group commits done to the binary log.
- https://mariadb.com/kb/en/group-commit-for-the-binary-log/
panels.title: Binlog_group_commits

panels.description: The number of bytes written to the binary log.
panels.title: Binlog_bytes_written

panels.description: The number of slave SQL threads running.
panels.title: Slaves_running

panels.description:
- IO(receiver) thread on a replica server
1: On, 0: Off
panels.title: ★ slave_io_running

panels.description:
- SQL  thread on a replica server
1: On, 0: Off
panels.title: ★ slave_sql_running

panels.description:
- = seconds_begind_master - sql_delay
- This is an indication of how “late” the replica
panels.title: ★ Slave Lag time(s)

list.label: Group
